G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the **Brockton District Court** pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Brockton, Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy does not exceed $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the **Brockton District Court** pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Brockton, Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy does not exceed $50,000.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an entity such as Defendant that undertakes to supervise minor children in its care owes **a duty of reasonable care** to protect those children from foreseeable harm.

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an entity such as Defendant that undertakes to supervise minor children in its care owes **a duty of reasonable care** to protect those children from foreseeable harm.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The provided passage is a dissent focused on causation, not duty, but Mullins v. Pine Manor College as a whole is a leading Massachusetts case recognizing that a college that undertakes to provide security for its (largely minor) resident students owes a duty of reasonable care to protect them from foreseeable criminal acts. The majority opinion (not reproduced here) expressly grounds liability in the college’s voluntary assumption of responsibility for students’ safety and the foreseeability of harm, which is analogous to entities supervising children in their care. Because only the dissent is quoted, the support is not explicit in this excerpt, but the full case clearly supports the proposition.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: Because the excerpt provided is solely Justice O’Connor’s dissent on proximate cause, it does not contain the majority’s duty analysis. In the full opinion, the court holds that Pine Manor College owed its student a duty to take reasonable measures to protect her against foreseeable criminal attacks, based on the college’s undertaking to provide security and the students’ reliance on that undertaking.

Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.raw_text: Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 Mass. 320 (1974)
Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an entity such as Defendant that undertakes to supervise minor children in its care owes **a duty of reasonable care** to protect those children from foreseeable harm.
Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.case_name: Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston
Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.support_reasoning: The case concerns an adult employee of an independent contractor injured while washing windows at the defendant club. The court discusses the club’s duty to such an employee as akin to that owed to its own employees, focusing on disclosure of hidden defects on the premises. It does not involve the supervision or care of minor children, nor does it articulate any special duty arising from undertaking to supervise minors; thus it does not support the specific proposition about entities supervising minor children in their care.
Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff was the employee of an independent contractor working on the club’s premises. The club thereby owed him the same duty it owed its own employees — to disclose hidden or concealed defects on the premises of which it was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care.”

Poplaski v. Lamphere, 422 Mass. 83 (1996.proposition: Defendant, through its employees, had a duty to **adequately supervise** all children in the after-school program, to maintain a safe environment, and to take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable injuries.
Poplaski v. Lamphere, 422 Mass. 83 (1996.case_name: Pappas Enterprises, Inc. v. Commerce & Industry Insurance
Poplaski v. Lamphere, 422 Mass. 83 (1996.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns interpretation of a statutory vacancy clause in a fire insurance policy and whether days of vacancy before or during prior policy periods count toward a 60‑day exclusion. It does not involve tort duties, child supervision, after‑school programs, or premises liability. Therefore it provides no authority for a duty to adequately supervise children or maintain a safe environment in an after‑school program context.
Poplaski v. Lamphere, 422 Mass. 83 (1996.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that the period of a vacancy existing prior to the date coverage is first effective should not be counted in determining whether a vacancy that excludes liability has occurred... We next consider whether the vacancy exclusion applies where, as here, the fire loss occurred during the first sixty days of the policy renewal and the vacancy had existed for more than sixty days before the date of the fire.

Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.raw_text: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc., 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633 (2002)
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.proposition: Defendant, through its employees, had a duty to **adequately supervise** all children in the after-school program, to maintain a safe environment, and to take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable injuries.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.case_name: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that the defendant, through its employees, had a duty to adequately supervise all children in an after-school program and maintain a safe environment. Coughlin v. Titus & Bean concerns an employer’s alleged negligent hiring/supervision of an employee who murdered a child near a warehouse; it analyzes whether the employer owed any duty at all to the victim and ultimately holds that no such duty existed under the circumstances. The opinion does not involve an after-school program, child supervision duties, or any analogous custodial/special relationship imposing a duty to supervise children; instead, it rejects the existence of a duty to protect the victim, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “Here, the motion judge ruled as matter of law that the defendant did not owe any duty to the victim. … In sum, a background check would not have provided any additional information that would have enabled Titus & Bean to reasonably foresee that Kelley posed a threat to members of the public at or near 385R Court Street. In any event, Kelley was to work alone at the warehouse and was not expected to have regular contact with the public in the normal course of business. Thus, in those circumstances, Titus & Bean could not have reasonably foreseen that Kelley posed a threat to members of the public, including the victim.”

Glidden v. Maglio, Inc., 430 Mass. 694 (.proposition: Defendant’s breach of its duty was negligent and constitutes a failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person or organization would have exercised under similar circumstances.
Glidden v. Maglio, Inc., 430 Mass. 694 (.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the elements of negligence and repeatedly refers to a "duty to use reasonable care," but it does not articulate or define negligence in the specific terms of the claimed proposition (i.e., that breach is "a failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person or organization would have exercised under similar circumstances"). Instead, the case turns on lack of proof of causation, not on elaborating the standard of care. Thus it does not serve as authority for the quoted definitional proposition.
Glidden v. Maglio, Inc., 430 Mass. 694 (.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendants negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts �a7 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law �a7 204 (2d ed. 1989).

Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.proposition: Defendant’s breach of its duty was negligent and constitutes a failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person or organization would have exercised under similar circumstances.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.support_reasoning: The case is about whether a social host owes any common-law duty to third parties injured by an intoxicated guest where the host did not serve or provide the alcohol. The court holds that no such duty exists under those circumstances and therefore there is no negligence; it does not state or apply a general standard that the defendant’s breach here was negligent or that it constituted a failure to exercise reasonable care. Instead, it rejects the existence of a duty altogether, which is contrary to the proposition claimed.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.relevant_excerpt: “Any liability on the defendant's part in such a situation must be grounded in the common law of negligence… meaning that the plaintiff has the burden of proving each and every element of that claim: duty, breach of duty (or, the element of negligence), causation (actual and proximate) and damages… Since no common law duty exists here, it follows that the statutes relied on by the plaintiff do not of themselves create a cause of action in tort.”

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the **direct and proximate cause** of Plaintiff’s son’s injuries, as the risk of physical harm from unsupervised rough play among children was a foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s failure to supervise.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The case concerns injuries caused by an intoxicated seaman operating an unsecured forklift and addresses whether the defendant’s negligence in failing to secure the forklift was a proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries, in light of the foreseeability of misuse by unauthorized persons. It does not involve children, rough play, or a failure to supervise children, nor does it discuss risks arising from unsupervised rough play among children. While it affirms that foreseeable wrongful third‑party conduct does not break the chain of causation, it cannot be accurately cited for the specific child‑supervision proposition stated.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury. The test is to be found in the probable injurious consequences which were to be anticipated….’ … Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable.”

Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 2.raw_text: Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 262 (1986)
Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 2.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the **direct and proximate cause** of Plaintiff’s son’s injuries, as the risk of physical harm from unsupervised rough play among children was a foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s failure to supervise.
Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 2.support_reasoning: The case is an automobile–pedestrian negligence action about a driver striking an adult pedestrian. It does not involve injuries to a child, failure to supervise children, or foreseeability of harm from rough play among children. Although the opinion uses standard causation language (“direct and proximate cause”), it provides no discussion or holding about the foreseeability of physical harm from unsupervised children’s play, so it cannot be cited as authority for that specific proposition.
Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 2.relevant_excerpt: “A defendant is negligent when he fails to use due care with respect to the plaintiff to whom he owes a duty of care and his failure to use such care is the direct and proximate cause of the injury or damage to the plaintiff.”

Glick v. Prince Italian Foods, Inc., 25.raw_text: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods, Inc., 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901 (1987)
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods, Inc., 25.proposition: Plaintiff and his son have suffered actual damages, including medical expenses, lost income, and pain and suffering, all proximately caused by Defendant’s negligent acts and omissions.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods, Inc., 25.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods, Inc., 25.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether the defendant restaurant owed a duty and whether the plaintiffs’ injuries were reasonably foreseeable; it does not discuss or establish that the plaintiffs actually incurred medical expenses, lost income, or pain and suffering, nor does it find those damages were proximately caused by the defendant’s negligence. In fact, the court concludes the incident was not reasonably foreseeable and that the defendant had no duty, effectively rejecting liability. Thus, the case does not support a proposition that plaintiffs suffered and proved actual damages proximately caused by defendant’s negligence.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods, Inc., 25.relevant_excerpt: “The undisputed facts of this case make the injuries suffered by the plaintiffs the result of an incident which was not reasonably foreseeable by the defendant and thus not an occurrence from which it had a duty to protect its patrons.”

Corsetti v. Stone Co., 396 Mass. 1 (1985.proposition: Plaintiff and his son have suffered actual damages, including medical expenses, lost income, and pain and suffering, all proximately caused by Defendant’s negligent acts and omissions.
Corsetti v. Stone Co., 396 Mass. 1 (1985.support_reasoning: The excerpt concerns evidentiary treatment of collateral source benefits and the scope of a narrow exception to the collateral source rule, not whether plaintiffs suffered actual damages such as medical expenses, lost income, and pain and suffering proximately caused by defendant’s negligence. It is a dissent focused on admissibility of certain impeachment evidence and appellate deference to trial court discretion. Nothing in the provided text establishes or analyzes the elements of damages or proximate cause as stated in the proposition.
Corsetti v. Stone Co., 396 Mass. 1 (1985.relevant_excerpt: "Collateral source evidence has been deemed irrelevant because 'the receipts from the outside source do not go to reduce the defendant’s liability; yet jurors might be led by the irrelevancy to consider plaintiffs’ claims unimportant or trivial or to refuse plaintiffs’ verdicts or reduce them, believing that otherwise there would be unjust double recovery.' Goldstein v. Gontarz, 364 Mass. 800, 809 (1974)."
